bestBHT.bht: During a customary feast dating back to the time of Judas Maccabaeus, Jesus walked in Solomon's portico to explain to Gentile readers why he enters by the door with the sheep. Referring to himself as a shepherd, Jesus distinguishes between true shepherds and the Pharisees, stressing that a shepherd is characterized by their role rather than their identity. He underscores the significance of divine commission and protection, highlighting himself as the shepherd who cares for and feeds the sheep, as well as any under shepherd authorized by Christ.

Henry Alford: This feast had become usual since the time when Judas Maccabæus purified the temple from the profanations of Antiochus."
It was held on Chisleu (December) 25, and seven following days.
The notice is inserted to explain to Gentile readers the reason of our Lord’s walking in Solomon’s portico.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 2. he that entereth in by the door
is the shepherd of the sheep—a true, divinely recognized
Albert Barnes: He that entereth by the door...become ministers of religion.
Marvin Vincent: The shepherd [ποιμην] . Better, a shepherd. It is the character rather than the person that is contemplated.
Archibald T. Robertson: The shepherd of the sheep (ποιμην εστιν των προβατων). No article with ποιμην, 'a shepherd to the sheep.' He comes in by the door with the sheep whom he leads."
Old word is ποιμην, root meaning to protect. Jesus applies it to himself in verse John 10:16 and implies it here.
Christ is drawing a sharp contrast after the conduct of the Pharisees towards the blind man between himself and them.
John Gill: But he that entereth in by the door,.... With a divine commission, and by a divine authority, who comes not of himself, but is sent; does not take the honour to himself, or thrust in himself, and assume an office to himself, but is called unto it, and invested in it"
he is the shepherd of the sheep; by whom Christ means himself, as is evident from John 10:11, whose the sheep are, and who takes care of them, and feeds them, as a shepherd does his flock"
and which holds true of any under shepherd, having his mission and commission, and deriving his authority from Christ.

bhtAttempts.bht: During a feast that was customary since the time of Judas Maccabaeus, Jesus walked in Solomon's portico to convey a message to Gentile readers. Referring to himself as a shepherd, he draws a stark contrast between true shepherds and the Pharisees. Jesus emphasizes that a shepherd is not just a person, but someone who genuinely protects the sheep. He enters by the door with the sheep, which signifies his divine commission and authority. This imagery highlights Jesus as the ultimate shepherd who cares for and feeds his flock, as well as any under shepherd who receives their mission and authority from Christ.

During a customary feast dating back to the time of Judas Maccabaeus, Jesus walked in Solomon's portico to explain to Gentile readers why he enters by the door with the sheep. Referring to himself as a shepherd, Jesus distinguishes between true shepherds and the Pharisees, stressing that a shepherd is characterized by their role rather than their identity. He underscores the significance of divine commission and protection, highlighting himself as the shepherd who cares for and feeds the sheep, as well as any under shepherd authorized by Christ.

During a customary feast held on December 25 and the following seven days, Jesus walked in Solomon's portico to clarify to Gentile readers the reason for his entrance through the door with the sheep. Describing himself as a shepherd, Jesus accentuates that it is the character, rather than the person, that is significant. He emphasizes his divine authority and care for the sheep, drawing a sharp contrast between himself and the Pharisees. This imagery applies to Christ as the ultimate shepherd and any under shepherd with a mission and authority derived from him.

During a customary feast on December 25 and the following seven days, Jesus walked in Solomon's portico to explain to Gentile readers the reason for his entrance through the door with the sheep. As he refers to himself as a shepherd, Jesus emphasizes that it is the character, rather than the person, that matters. He underscores his divine authority and care for the sheep, highlighting the contrast between himself and the Pharisees. This imagery applies to both Christ as the ultimate shepherd and any under shepherd with a mission and authority given by him.

During a customary feast on December 25 and the following seven days, Jesus walked in Solomon's portico to clarify the reason for entering through the door with the sheep. He describes himself as a shepherd, emphasizing the importance of character. Jesus underscores his divine authority and care for the sheep, contrasting himself with the Pharisees. This imagery applies to Christ as the ultimate shepherd and any under shepherd with a mission and authority derived from him.
